docs.lead_paragraph: The Times's virtual round table of voters talked about the recent debates in New Hampshire.
docs.abstract: Our Open Caucus respondents weigh in on the weekend's debates in New Hampshire.
docs.snippet: Our Open Caucus respondents weigh in on the weekend's debates in New Hampshire.

docs.lead_paragraph: More so than any credit card, library card or health insurance card, the MetroCard is the one piece of plastic that most unites New Yorkers. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority distributes 180 million of them -- that's not a typo -- every year. The MetroCard is a fixture of anyone's pocket, wallet or purse, a mainstay for any commuter, and -- ever since the last tokens were phased out in 2003 -- the only one way to (legally) ride a subway in New York City. And yet, few people spend much time looking at or thinking about the humble, homely MetroCard.

headline.main: Does the MetroCard Need a Makeover?

docs.abstract: The MetroCard's yellow and blue design hasn't changed for a decade. Should it? A panel of experts takes up the question, and an M.T.A. official tells us why he likes the card just the way it is.
docs.snippet: The MetroCard's yellow and blue design hasn't changed for a decade. Should it? A panel of experts takes up the question, and an M.T.A. official tells us why he likes the card just the way it is.

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, the drug industry has claimed that poor people benefit from the billions of dollars worth of free drugs that are distributed to doctors every year.
docs.abstract: Drug freebies end up in the hands of the wealthy, not the poor, a new study shows.
docs.snippet: Drug freebies end up in the hands of the wealthy, not the poor, a new study shows.

byline.contributor: Michael Cooper reported from Manchester, N.H., and Robert Pear from Washington.
byline.original: By MICHAEL COOPER  and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Time magazine political blog The Page reported on Saturday, a group of American Federation of State, Civil and Municipal Employees leaders from around the country has written a letter to the union's International chiefs protesting their production of mailings and radio ads attacking Senator Barack Obama's health care proposals.
docs.abstract: The union's International president said that ads criticizing Obama's health care plan did not amount to a negative campaign tactic.
docs.snippet: The union's International president said that ads criticizing Obama's health care plan did not amount to a negative campaign tactic.
